an5.75:4.1: “Mendicants, these five warriors are found in the world.
an5.75:4.3: Firstly, one warrior falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.
an5.75:4.5: This is the first warrior found in the world.
an5.75:5.1: Furthermore, one warrior can face a cloud of dust,
an5.75:5.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sight of a banner’s crest. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.
an5.75:5.4: This is the second warrior found in the world.
an5.75:6.1: Furthermore, one warrior can face a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,
an5.75:6.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.
an5.75:6.4: This is the third warrior found in the world.
an5.75:7.1: Furthermore, one warrior can face a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil,
an5.75:7.2: but he’s killed or injured when blows are struck.
an5.75:7.4: This is the fourth warrior found in the world.
an5.75:8.1: Furthermore, one warrior can face a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil and being struck.
an5.75:8.2: He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.
an5.75:8.4: This is the fifth warrior found in the world.
an5.75:8.5: These are the five warriors found in the world.
an5.75:9.1: In the same way, these five people similar to warriors are found among the monks.
an5.75:9.3: Firstly, one monk falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:9.4: Declaring his inability to continue training, he abandons it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:9.7: ‘In such and such a village or town there’s a women or a girl who is attractive, good-looking, impressive, a perfect flower of beauty.’
an5.75:9.8: Hearing this, he falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:9.9: Declaring his inability to continue training, he abandons it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:10.1: I say that this person is like the warrior who falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust.
an5.75:10.4: This is the first person similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:11.1: Furthermore, one monk can face a cloud of dust,
an5.75:11.2: but at the mere sight of a banner’s crest he falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:11.3: Declaring his inability to continue training, he abandons it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:11.5: It’s when a monk doesn’t hear:
an5.75:11.6: ‘In such and such a village or town there’s a women or a girl who is attractive, good-looking, impressive, a perfect flower of beauty.’
an5.75:11.7: But he sees for himself a women or a girl who is attractive, good-looking, impressive, a perfect flower of beauty.
an5.75:11.8: Seeing her, he falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:11.9: Declaring his inability to continue training, he abandons it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:12.1: I say that this person is like the warrior who can face a cloud of dust,
an5.75:12.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sight of a banner’s crest.
an5.75:12.5: This is the second person similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:13.1: Furthermore, one monk can face a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,
an5.75:13.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to enter the battle.
an5.75:13.3: Declaring his inability to continue training, he abandons it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:13.5: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, when a female comes up to him. She smiles, chats, laughs, and flirts with him.
an5.75:13.6: He falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.
an5.75:13.7: Declaring his inability to continue training, he abandons it and returns to a lesser life.
an5.75:14.1: I say that this person is like the warrior who can face a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,
an5.75:14.2: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil.
an5.75:14.5: This is the third person similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:15.1: Furthermore, one monk can face a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil,
an5.75:15.2: but he’s killed or injured when blows are struck.
an5.75:15.4: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, when a female comes up to him. She sits right by him, lies down, or embraces him.
an5.75:15.5: Without abandoning the training and declaring his inability to continue, he has sex.
an5.75:16.1: I say that this person is like the warrior who can face a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil, but is killed or injured when blows are struck.
an5.75:16.4: This is the fourth person similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:17.1: Furthermore, one monk can face a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil, and being struck. He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.
an5.75:17.3: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, when a female comes up to him. She sits right by him, lies down, or embraces him.
an5.75:17.4: But he disentangles and frees himself, and goes wherever he wants.
an5.75:17.5: He frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
an5.75:18.1: Gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he sits down in the meditation posture, with his body erect, and establishes his mindfulness right there.
an5.75:18.2: Giving up desire for the world, he meditates with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire.
an5.75:18.3: Giving up ill will, he meditates with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all creatures, cleansing the mind of ill will.
an5.75:18.4: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, he meditates with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
an5.75:18.5: Giving up restlessness and remorse, he meditates without restlessness, his mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
an5.75:18.6: Giving up doubt, he meditates having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about wholesome qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
an5.75:18.7: He gives up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, he enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.
an5.75:19.1: When his mind has unified in samādhi like this—purified, bright, spotless, rid of taints, pliable, workable, steady, and motionless—he turns it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
an5.75:19.2: He truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. He truly understands: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
an5.75:19.3: Knowing and seeing like this, his mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire for rebirth, and ignorance.
an5.75:19.4: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
an5.75:20.1: I say that this person is like the warrior who can face a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil and being struck. He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.
an5.75:20.4: This is the fifth person similar to a warrior found among the monks.
an5.75:20.5: These five people similar to warriors are found among the monks.”
